<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 828, 91]]<|/det|> A student investigates the period of a pendulum. Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2 show the set-up. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 98, 756, 330]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 344, 376, 362]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[596, 344, 668, 362]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 375, 146, 394]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 375, 912, 394]]<|/det|> Explain briefly how to measure to the centre of the pendulum bob as accurately as possible. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 435, 920, 453]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 466, 146, 485]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 466, 920, 500]]<|/det|> The student adjusts the length of the pendulum until the distance \(l\), measured from the bottom of the clamp supporting the pendulum to the centre of the pendulum bob, is \(50.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 514, 920, 547]]<|/det|> He displaces the bob slightly and releases it so that it swings. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 560, 688, 579]]<|/det|> He measures and records the time \(t\) for 20 complete oscillations. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 592, 180, 610]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 592, 920, 625]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 612, 920, 630]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 638, 178, 656]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 638, 611, 656]]<|/det|> Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the value of \(T^2\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 638, 920, 656]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 669, 539, 687]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 695, 808, 847]]<|/det|>
l/cmt/sT/s\(T^{2}/s^{2}\)
50.028.2
60.031.21.562.43
70.033.61.682.82
80.035.81.793.20
90.038.21.913.65
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 863, 920, 897]]<|/det|> He repeats the procedure using \(l\) values of \(60.0 \text{cm}\), \(70.0 \text{cm}\), \(80.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\). The readings and results are shown in Table 1.1.

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the horizontal distance travelled by a metal ball after it rolls off the end of a plastic track. Fig. 4.1 shows the set-up.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
The ball rolls down a plastic track. The left-hand side of the track is fixed. The right-hand side can be adjusted so that the ball comes off the track at different angles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
The student measures the horizontal distance that the ball travels from the right-hand end of the track to the point that it hits the floor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the horizontal distance travelled by the metal ball depends on the angle that the right-hand end of the track makes with the bench.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 255, 892, 453]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 467, 532, 486]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>
